loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta B. is from the village of Owaon. She is 39 years old. Julieta is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Julieta raises and sells pigs. Julieta has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP average per month from these activities.

In 2008, Julieta joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This will be Julieta's 4th loan from PMPC and her third time on Kiva. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions and pay for her children's education. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: Lina

texts.en:
Mrs. Lina A. is 59 years old and married, and is a resident of Maquilao, Tangub City. She and her husband were blessed with 5 children, 3 of whom are married. The rest of the children are still single and in their adolescent stage. 

The couple are primarily engaged in fishing. They own and operate fish traps known locally as “bunsod” (pictured). For over 30 years, they’ve been in this kind of business and have used it to support their family. Now, they earn an average net income of at least PHP 4,000.00, which benefits their family.  

Now on her fifth loan with a good credit record, Lina was given the privilege of borrowing PHP 8,000.00 to buy additional fishing nets for her bunsod. She will use the future income from this loan to meet her family's daily needs, repay her loan, and save for the future. She hopes that this project will result in a good catch with God’s help.

loans.use: To buy fishing nets for her bunsod (fish corrals)

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia L. is from the village of Miaray in Dangcagan, Bukidnon. Lilia is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Lilia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over 35 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Lilia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lilia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 19000 PHP from HSPFI. She used her previous loan to expand her business. Lilia is requesting a new loan of 22000 PHP that will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be Lilia's 14th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn P. is from the village of Victoria in Alicia, Isabela. She is 34 years old. Marilyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marilyn sells "sawali" and "cogon" (long grasses that, when dried, are used for the roofs and walls of houses) in the local community. Marilyn has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities. 

In 2009, Marilyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilyn is requesting a loan of 10000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Marilyn's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: 
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Saudie

texts.en:
Mr. Saudie T. is from the village of Southern Poblacion in Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. He is 34 years old. He is married and blessed with only one school-aged child. He owns and operates an agricultural business. His income comes primarily from the cocoa that he grows on his land. He earns 6,000.00 PHP each month from his business and he will use this money to repay his loan. 

In 2007, he joined PMPC to gain access its programs and services. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000.00 PHP from PMPC. He is requesting a new loan of 50,000.00 PHP to buy materials to construct a fence (pictured) and and renovate his house.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For house repair and fence construction

loans.name: Tav

texts.en:
Mrs. Tav K. is 44 years old. She lives in Ta Koam Village in Takeo Province. She breeds pigs and makes rice wine. Since her pig-breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets. With the rest of the loan, she will buy the rice to make her rice wine.  

Her husband, Mr. So Khlot, is a house builder who does not earn enough income to support his family. Mrs. Tav K. is a mother of three children. One of her children is an employee in the garment factory, one is a housekeeper, and the youngest is a student in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and rice for her rice wine business

loans.name: Maybileen's Group

texts.en:
Maybileen R. is from the village of Magassi in Cabagan, Isabela. She is 31 years old. Maybileen is the leader of a 8-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Maybileen R..

Maybileen is single. To make a living, Maybileen raises and sells pigs. Maybileen has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Maybileen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maybileen is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP to purchase piglets to raise and sell in the future. This will be Maybileen's second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy piglets

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Mrs.Vilma R. is 42 years old. She is from Miligan, Molave, Zamboanga del Sur. She is married to a farmer and blessed with four children.  The family operates a sari-sari store and has kept it going for three years. They are fortunate to have a monthly income of PHP 3,000 that they use for their daily consumption. 

Vilma joined Paglaum for their credit services. Now, she is applying for a loan to purchase additional items for her inventory. She plans to use the additional revenue to expand her sari-sari store.

loans.use: To expand her sari-sari store

loans.name: Mrs. Sokhen Menh Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhen M. is 44 years old. She is the president of a village bank that consists of 18 people who live in TrapE. Phlong Village in Takeo Province. All the members will be using their loans to support their families and for different purpose. 

Mrs. Sokhen M. is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Samaiy Oun, is a teacher in the local village. Even though they try to work hard in their businesses, they still cannot support their family members. 

Thus, Mrs. Sokhen M. wants to start a new business to improve their living conditions. She has decided to ask for a loan to buy pigs to breed. She will use the rest of the loan to buy equipment and supplies to construct a pigpen. 

Mrs. Sokhen M. is the mother of four children. One of her children is an employee in a garment factory, one does housework, and the other two are students in the local school. All of the members of the village bank are shown in the photo, but some of thE. are blocked.

loans.use: To buy pigs to breed and supplies to build a pigpen

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
Chum D., age 55, is married and lives with her two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. D. has a business selling a kind of tropical fruit, fish, and vegetables everywhere in her village. She is able to earn an income of USD $5.00 per day. The family is also assisted by one of her children who is employed in a local garment factory and earns an income of USD $2.30 per day. 

D. and her family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses and reduce their daily expenses. Therefore, D. is requesting a loan of US $1200 from CREDIT, a Kiva field partner. She wants to use the expected loan to buy more fish and vegetables to sell to her new and existing customers at the market. This is her fourth loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy more fish and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Jovinsol's Group

texts.en:
Jovinsol C. is from the village of Bonfal East in Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 35 years old. Jovinsol is the leader of a 10-member loan group sponsored by ASKI. Although each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for repaying the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Jovinsol is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Jovinsol owns and operates a general store where she sells a variety of different products in the local community. Jovinsol has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Jovinsol joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovinsol is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Jovinsol's first loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hannah Nyambura

texts.en:
Hannah is 46 years old and married, and she has two children. She and her husband, Francis, both sell flowers. She supplies flowers in wholesale to small retailers. They live in the Gitaru, Kikuyu area. They operate their flower businesses in Nairobi’s Westland’s area, which is a busy and strategic area for this kind of a business. This has made it possible for her to get good returns.

Hannah was introduced to KADET by a friend and she has no previous credit history. This will be her first loan with KADET. She will use the loan she has applied for to buy more flowers and open a green-grocer stall as a secondary business.

Hannah plans to enlarge her business and she hopes to export her flowers. This will give her better business opportunities.

loans.use: Hannah wants to expand her flower business and open a green-grocer stall.

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Phorn C. lives in a small wooden house from which she operates a small enterprise, selling breakfast foods to the neighbors. She is able to earn approximately $3 each day. For another source of income, her husband drives a trailer-motor taxi. 

Presently she faces difficulties with her living situation because her house is too old and too small for them. She wants a new house, but she doesn’t have enough money yet to start the construction. So, she is applying for her second loan to buy housing materials for building a new house.

loans.use: To buy materials for building a new house.

loans.name: Julita

texts.en:
Julita B. is from the village of Miaray in Dangcagan, Bukidnon. Julita is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Julita owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Julita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Julita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from HSPFI. Julita is requesting a new loan of 9000 PHP to expand her business. This will be Julita's 9th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David M. is 57 years old. He has a hardware business in the Bondeni area in Bungoma town in Western Kenya. He is married to Lucy Wesonga and they have four children, all of whom are grown and married.

David hopes to get a loan through Kadet Limited to enable him get enough money to add more stock to his hardware business. He plans to buy 10 liters of grand paints, nails, and window glass, and use some of the money for family upkeep for him and the wife.

His dream for the future is to expand the business into a big hardware shop by selling iron sheets and cement.

loans.use: To buy paint and nails, to add to the inventory of his hardware shop

loans.name: Geoffrey

texts.en:
Geoffrey O. is a businessman in Bungoma, which is a town in Western Province of Kenya. He is married to Hellen O. and they have four children. Their first-born son is 26 years old and in college and the last-born just graduated from high school.

Geoffrey currently provides laundry services for a fee and is looking for more funds to add inventory to his business. He is planning to buy laundry chemicals and wrapping paper. He will use part of the money to pay the staff’s salaries and the remaining money for family upkeep. Geoffrey borrowed his first loan from us. He completed payment of the loan successfully without problems. 

His desire is to buy an original dry-cleaning machine to improve his general performance and also to expand his business into wholesale so he can to create more employment opportunities.

loans.use: To buy laundry chemicals and wrapping paper, and to add to his inventory

loans.name: Thoang

texts.en:
Thoang C. L., age 52, is a widow who lives with her sister in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. L. buys and sells rice and is also employed in the village. She is able to earn an income of USD $4 per day. The family is also assisted by her sister who buys rice to sell and earns an income of USD $2 per day. 

L. and her family members try to work hard and help each others to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses and reduce their daily expenses. Therefore, L. is requesting for a loan of US $400 from CREDIT, a Kiva field partner. She wants to use the loan to buy more rice when the price is good enough to make a profit. This is her sixth loan from CREDIT. 

L. is pictured here in a sky-blue shirt.

loans.use: To buy rice to sell

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda B. is from the village of San Antonio. She is 44 years old. Erlinda is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Erlinda plants, harvests, and sells a variety of vegetables in the local community. Erlinda also has a grocery store. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2006, Erlinda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from PMPC. She used her previous loan to purchase construction materials to improve her house. 

Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP to purchase additional inventory and use as working capital for the grocery business. She will also buy fertilizer for her vegetable garden. This will be Erlinda's 7th loan from PMPC and second loan from Kiva. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's living conditions. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her vegetable garden and more inventory for her grocery store

loans.name: Alona

texts.en:
Alona R. is from the village of Malipayon in Pangantucan, Bukidnon. Alona is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Alona owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store where she sells food and daily-use products in the local community. Alona has been engaged in her business for over 12 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Alona joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alona has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. Alona is requesting a new loan of 17000 PHP to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Alona's 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay for her children's education. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is 47 years old and a single mother to two boys. She lives in Kawangware, a slum area where she has put up an open-air stall to sell second-hand clothes. She sells her clothes to small-scale retailers around the Kawangware area. This is a very highly populated area and, thus, she gets many customers to sustain her business.

She was introduced to KADET by her friend. She has never before borrowed from other sources. This will be her first loan with KADET. Salome plans to use her loan to add more clothes to her business inventory.

She also hopes that she will enlarge her business and distribute clothing to other small retailers.

loans.use: Salome wants to buy more bales of second-hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Heng

texts.en:
Heng C., age 42, is married and lives with her four children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. C. is in a business of selling smoked fish. She is able to earn a gross income of USD $30 per day. The family is also assisted by her husband, a skilled fisherman who earns a gross income of USD $16 per day. 

C. and her family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses and reduce their daily expenses. Therefore, C. is requesting a loan of US $1000 from CREDIT, a Kiva field partner. She wants to use the  loan to buy more smoked fish to sell. This is her fourth loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy more smoked fish to sell

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Mrs. Ros S., 61, is married to Varin, age 80. They both are older parents who are blessed with six children, four of whom are married and two are single. Presently Ros S. and her husband depend on income from their children, who are working at different occupations. Four of their children work in the garment factory and another one is a civil servant officer. Ros S. has an old house that needs repair. Due to her lack of money, she decided to apply for a loan through Kiva, which she will use to repair her existing house.

loans.use: To repair her existing house.

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en: Cristina S. is from the village of Barangay Dos. She is 55 years old, is married, and has five adult children. Cristina owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month. She is also engaged in selling snacks in the local community. In 2006, Cristina joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. Cristina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies and as additional capital for her snack-selling business. This loan will be her 7th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.  About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies and to use as additional capital for her snack-selling business

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en:
Roseline is 42 years old, married, and has two teenage daughters, ages 13 and 17. She is requesting a loan of 20,000 KES in order to buy feed for her chickens, which she raises in order to sell their eggs to residents in the surrounding area. 

Roseline also makes cleaning products and detergents for individual use and sells those products both to hotels and in residential areas. 

Her biggest challenges are lack of available capital and adequate means of transportation. She has been in her current line of business for eight years. She wants to be a major supplier of her products within 5 years and hopes to have a better life. She considers herself hardworking, patient, focused and welcoming.

loans.use: feed for chickens

loans.name: Wilma's Group

texts.en: Wilma A. is from the village of Remus, Baggao, Cagayan. She is 46 years old. Wilma is the group leader of an 18-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Wilma is widowed and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Wilma raises pigs for sale. Wilma has been engaged in her business for over 23 years and earns approximately 8,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Wilma joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Wilma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. Wilma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the second loan taken out by Wilma from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Krouch

texts.en:
Krouch L. is a widow who lives with her two school-aged children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. L. is a chef for a Korean restaurant in the city. She is able to earn an income of $100 per month.

L. and her family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well to keep up with the daily necessary expenses. Therefore, L. is requesting a loan of $1,000 from CREDIT, a Kiva partner. She wants to use the loan to buy a motorbike to commute to work. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to commute to work

loans.name: Vang

texts.en:
Vang E., 39 years old, is a good mother blessed with four children. Her three grown children go to school or to work at different occupations while the other one is married.

To earn a living, Vang E. and her husband are domestic workers at a construction location. They are also hired by neighbors to build their houses in the village.

Vang E. has a single son who wants to have a partner in his wife and needs to have a wedding party, but Vang E. doesn’t have money yet to have a party. Therefore, she has requested a loan of $500 in order to perform a party, if possible.

loans.use: To perform a wedding party.

loans.name: Enos Ndoga

texts.en:
Enos M. is running a restaurant business in Rosta Mai, a town in the Kakamega area in western Kenya. He is married to Judith Mukhenje, who is a local farmer. They have four children; three boys and a girl. The eldest son started high school this year while the last-born is 3 years old. 

Enos has been running his business for the past four years and as a result of the good service and meals offered there, he has made very many loyal clients. He has applied for a loan so that he can be able to buy a dairy cow, four sacks of Irish potatoes, four crates of sodas and four bundles of baking flour to add to the food stock in his restaurant. This will enable him to meet the different demands and choices of his clients.

He hopes to open up another restaurant in the nearby town once he gets enough funds. He also hopes to buy a pickup vehicle to help his wife carry farming supplies to the market for sale.

loans.use: Add Irish potatoes, one sack of onions, wheat flour, etc., to his stock in the restuarant

loans.name: Saylamo

texts.ru: Хасанова Сайламо проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст, 49 лет. Замужем, имеет одного ребенка. Хасанова Сайламо имеет высшее образование по специальности "Товаровед". В области торговли работает более чем 28 лет. Она торгует в своем собственном магазине. Кредит берет для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Saylamo H. lives in the city of Kulob. She is 49 years old, married and has one child. Saylamo has a higher education in the merchandiser specialty. She has been working in the retail sales field for over 28 years. She sells at her own store. She is requesting this loan in order to increase goods turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increasing goods turnover

loans.name: Lillian

texts.en:
Lillian O. is married to Robert Otani and they have three children. They live in Maraba, a town in Kakamega, in the western part of Kenya. Lillian’s husband is a journalist and all their children are still in school.

Lillian runs a boutique and has been doing it for the past year. She has applied for a loan which will enable her to add more new clothing stock to her business. She intends to buy ready-made clothes and cosmetics and use the rest of the money to pay her rent.

Her future dream is to expand the boutique into a wholesale shop and diversify into the transport business.

loans.use: Buy more clothes to add to her stock

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia R. is from the village of Malipayon, Pangantucan Bukidnon. Lydia is married. To make a living, Lydia owns & operates tailoring business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing general tailoring repairs in the local community. Lydia has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Lydia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lydia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. Lydia is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional materials to improve the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials to improve the business

loans.name: Josephine's Group

texts.en:
Josephine D. C. is from the village of Olango, Mallig, Isabela. She is 45 years old. Josephine is the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Josephine is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the second loan taken out by Josephine from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Chan

texts.en: Chan K. S. is married and lives with her two school-aged children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. S. is a skillful chef. She provides her cooking services to rich people at rental apartments and is able to earn an income of USD 7 per day. Her husband is a soldier in Siem Reap Province, earning an income of USD 4.60 per day. S. and her family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. And they are seeking to improve their businesses as well as to cope with their daily necessary expenses. Therefore, S. is requesting a loan of US $1200 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. She wants to use the expected loan to buy a motorbike to commute to work. This is her first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: buy a motorbike to commute to work

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Mrs. Ly S. currently sells porridge to her nearby villagers for breakfast. She is married with three kids, all of whom attend school and need her care. 

Her husband helps support the family by driving a motorcycle taxi. He is able to generate $5 per day.  Recently his income has been declining due to the fact that his taxi is often broken and is not attractive to the passengers.

To solve the problem, Ly S. is applying for a loan for her husband to hire a repairman to repair his broken taxi. (Mrs. Ly S.'s husband is pictured.)

loans.use: To hire a repairman to repair his broken taxi.

loans.name: Karen

texts.en:
Karen B. is from the village of Malipayon, Pangantucan Bukidnon. Karen is single. To make a living, Karen owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Karen has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Karen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Karen has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. Karen is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by Karen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Josie's Group

texts.en:
Josie C. is from the village of Union Kalinga, Luna, Isabela. She is 42 years old. Josie is the group leader of a 9-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Josie is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Josie owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Josie has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Josie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josie is requesting a new loan of 4,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Josie from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Phourng

texts.en:
Phourng P., 45, is married and lives with his four children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. P. is in a business as a real estate agent. He provides services to people who want to buy or sell their land in the province. He is able to earn an income of USD 12 per day. His wife grows morning glories as food for sale, earning an income of USD 7 per day.

P. and his family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. And they are seeking to improve their businesses as well as to cope with their daily necessary expenses. Therefore, P. is requesting a loan of US$ 800 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. He wants to use the expected loan to buy more morning glory seeds to produce more output. This is his first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: buy morning glories seeds to grow more vegetables

loans.name: Buth

texts.en:
Buth S., 32, has a business making and selling brooms at a local market in Takeo province to earn approximately US$ 4 each day. Her husband stays at home and helps her making brooms. The brooms are made from a kind of tall grass which grows in the forest. Both husband and wife learned how to make brooms from their neighbors and they started doing that business back in 2002. This couple has two school-aged children.

Buth S. told a loan officer that every month she needs to spend around US$ 45 on food and US$ 5 on utilities. Buth S. is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase the tall grass in bulk. This will save money and allow her to increase the number of brooms they can make. (Buth is pictured with her husband and her child.)

loans.use: purchasing tall grass in bulk to make brooms

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn M. is from the village of Malipayon, Pangantucan Bukidnon. Jocelyn is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Jocelyn owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Jocelyn has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Jocelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jocelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. Jocelyn is requesting same loan amount of 14,000 PHP which will be used to invest in renovating the business. This will be the 5th loan taken out by Jocelyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in renovating the business

loans.name: Thaong

texts.en:
Thaong P., 30, has a business making and selling brooms at the local market of Takeo province to earn approximately US$ 3 each day. Broom are made from a kind of tall grass which grows in the forest. She learned how to make brooms from her neighbors and they started doing that business back in 2005. She told a loan officer that every month she needs to spend around US$ 30 on food and US$ 5 on utilities.

Thaong P. is asking for a loan of US$ 1200 to purchase a motorbike to transport her brooms to sell at the market.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane V. is from the town of Quezon, San Isidro, Isabela. She is 47 years old. Mary Jane is married and has 3 school-aged children. Mary Jane owns and operates a furniture making business. The main source of income for the business comes from making and selling general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Mary Jane has been involved in her business for over five years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Mary Jane joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane is requesting her first loan, of 50000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to make additional furniture

loans.name: Felista

texts.en: Felista is 27 years old and a mother of one. She operates a hardware business in Kiambu where she sells timber, off cuts, firewood and furniture. She employs two people and describes her business environment as busy. She sells her products to carpenters, locals and institutions within Kiambu town. She is requesting a second loan of 60,000 KES from Faulu Kenya Limited to purchase timber and cedar posts. She hopes to acquire a truck for her business in the future. She describes herself as aggressive in business.

loans.use: to buy timber and cedar posts

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas M. was born in 1949. She is a widow and the mother of three children. One of her children is married and started a new home. Meas M. has a son who is skilled in repairing mobile phones and currently he uses his knowledge to invest in a phone sale business, the proceeds from which helps provide food for the family.  Her son-in-law is a carpenter.

Meas M. owns a few machines that she uses to sew clothing for her villagers for money. She has a daughter who works with her in sewing clothing. Meas M. complains that she always faces difficulty with transportation because she has no vehicle for traveling purposes. She hopes to reduce this problem by looking for a loan from Kiva to buy an old motorcycle to use as transportation.

loans.use: To buy an old motorcycle to use as transportation.

loans.name: Cheryl

texts.en:
Cheryl N. is from the village of Malipayon, Pangantucan Bukidnon. Cheryl is married and has 2 school-aged children. Cheryl owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Cheryl has been involved in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Cheryl joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Cheryl has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from HSPFI. For her 6th loan, Cheryl is requesting the same amount of 14000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children's education . 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sar

texts.en: Sar R., age 29, is married and lives with her husband in the Takeo province. She is an employee selling zoo tickets at Tamao Mountain. On average, she is able to make about 2 USD each day. Her husband is a motorbike mechanic and also a construction worker in homebuilding. He typically makes 4 USD each day. Sar R. would like a loan of 700 USD to make a new investment. She will use this money to raise cows.

loans.use: To raise cows

loans.name: Muthama

texts.en:
Muthama is 36 years old, married, and has a four-year-old son. He is the owner of a retail shop that sells milk, bread, margarine, sugar, flour and other essential basic foodstuffs in Mombassa, Kenya. He has one employee, and his business is located in a low- to medium-income area. He also runs a restaurant.
Muthama wants to improve his business to better provide for his family. In the future he wants to grow his retail business into a wholesale business. He describes himself as serious in business and ready to learn.

loans.use: To buy a refrigerator

loans.name: Sam

texts.en: Sam R. is 23 years old, and she sells fruit in the Takeo province. Her business has been around for about four years, and she makes 1.60 USD every day. Her husband is a construction worker in homebuilding. On average, he makes 4 USD a day. Selling fruit has been a difficult business. There is high inflation, and weather conditions have not been conducive to a good growing season. Therefore, she is asking for a loan of 500 USD to make a new investment. She would like to sell chickens during Chinese New Year.

loans.use: To purchase chickens to sell

loans.name: Mohammad Esmail

texts.en: M. Esmail, son of A. M., is married and lives with his own family. He has a butcher's business and has been involved in this line of work for a long time. He used his first loan to further his business. Now he plans to enlarge his business and is therefore requesting a second loan of 50,000 AFN to enlarge his shop and purchase more stock. He is happy to receive his second-cycle loan.

loans.use: To enlarge his shop and purchase more stock

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella M. is married to Charles Omili and they have four children: one boy and two girls who are all in primary school. They live in the Malakisi area near Kakamega town.

Stella is a plumber and very hardworking. Due to the fact that she is a woman doing this kind of job it has given her a lot of publicity which has made her get very many clients.

Stella has applied for a loan which she will use to buy more fittings for her plumbing work. She plans to use the profits made from this business to pay school fees for her children and also to cater for their daily needs.

Stella’s desire is to buy a personal plot in the future and build a kindergarten school because she has seen the need to have a local school since the one available is miles away.

loans.use: To buy more plumbing fittings

loans.name: Vugar

texts.en:
Vugar G. is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town, but is now settled in Absheron town, Masazir village. He is 43 years old. Vugar is married and has 2 children.

He has been in this business for 10 years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy 15 sheep to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy 15 sheep

loans.name: Gaudencia

texts.en:
Gaudencia Y. is from the village of Langcataon, Pangantucan Bukidnon. Gaudencia is married and has 3 adult-aged children.

To make a living, Gaudencia owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. Although not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Gaudencia has been engaged in her business for over 30 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Gaudencia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gaudencia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 17,000 PHP from HSPFI. Gaudencia is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to expand her business. This loan will be the 6th loan taken out by Gaudencia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Phun

texts.en:
Phun S., 29, is married and lives with his four-year-old child in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia.

S. is employed as a worker in a drinking water company in the city. He has been in this job since 2003 and is able to earn an income of USD 5 per day. His wife sells cosmetic products at a local market in the city, earning a gross income of USD 24 per day.

S. and her family members try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for their family. They are seeking to improve their businesses as well as reduce their daily necessary expenses. This is why S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

He wants to use the expected loan to buy more cosmetics products for sale and to expand his wife's current business. This is his first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics products for sale

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en: Fatmeh is a 23-year-old single woman. In 2006, she decided to open a beauty salon in her town after seeing a need for such a service in the region. This young woman is very talented and caters to a wide range of clientele in the village and its neighborhoods. Today, Fatmeh is requesting to borrow $1,200 to purchase beauty products and hair accessories in order to meet her clients' demands.

loans.use: purchase beauty products and hair accessories

loans.name: Kang

texts.en:
C., 29, lives in the rural area of Phnom Penh city. Her husband operates a motorcycle sale trade, and they have two school-aged children.
C. earns a living as a farmer by planting rice and vegetable crops. Recently she has been in need of some fertilizer for her crops, so she is requesting a loan to purchase a sack of fertilizer.

loans.use: To purchase a sack of fertilizer

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 26 years old and married to Peter Ndung'u, a businessman. They live in Ruaka from where she operates her beauty salon. Joyce's main customers are from the neighborhood.

Joyce has never borrowed from other sources and this is her first loan with KADET. She was introduced to KADET by her friend and she is among the founding members of her group. When she gets this loan, Joyce plans to expand the salon business and buy stock for a boutique she is creating in her salon. 

Joyce hopes and plans to operate an even bigger salon and a boutique.

loans.use: to expand the salon business and open a boutique

loans.name: Myline

texts.en:
Myline, 32 years old, is a married woman who lives in Agusan Del Sur. She has a 6-year-old child. Myline has been involved in rice farming since 2002. Farming is her family’s only source of income so she and her husband make sure the crops are healthy. She gives her best for the farm to be productive because it is very helpful in sustaining her family’s needs.

Myline is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP. She will use this loan to acquire farming supplies such as seeds and fertilizers. Receiving this loan is truly helpful to Myline’s farming.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Martha Wanjiru

texts.en:
Martha is 32 years old and married with two children. Her husband, Nahashon, is a businessman. 

Martha is a farmer and this she has done for the last seven years. After harvesting, she sells her produce to small-scale traders in the area. So far she is doing well as she is able to chip in to the family income kitty and also provide food for her family.

Martha was introduced to KADET by her friends and she is among her group’s founding members. She has not borrowed from other sources and this is her first loan with KADET. She plans to use the loan to buy more seeds in readiness for the next planting season.

Martha hopes that in future she will be able to farm on a large scale and be able to meet her customers’ needs.

loans.use: To buy more seeds in readiness for the next planting season

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy has been married to Reynaldo for seventeen years now. She is 41 years old and has seven children with the oldest being fourteen years old.

Lucy farms for a living, growing rice crops on her farm. When not busy farming, she spends her time raising pigs to add to her family’s income.

Lucy joined CEVI to expand her business opportunities. She requested a loan of Php 7,000 which she will use to purchase seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs. She will also use some to buy feed for her pigs.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Eang

texts.en:
Mrs. Eang L. is 40 years old and lives in Prey Pnhi village in Takeo province. She is the mother of three children who are all students in the local school. Her husband, Mr Khom Yors, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he cultivates rice. He is shown on the left in the photo.

Mrs. Eang L. is a silk weaver who is able to earn a small income to support the family. Since her business is going well, she would like to increase it and continue to expand it so she decided to ask for a loan to buy silk. The rest of the loan she would use to buy supplies and equipment to support her silk weaving.

loans.use: To buy more silk plus supplies and equipment to support her silk weaving

loans.name: Milagros

texts.en: Milagros A. is from the village of Barangay Dos. She is 40 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Milagros owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns an average of approximately 2,000 PHP per month. In 2006, Milagros joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. Milagros is requesting a new loan of 5,500 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This loan will be her 8th from PMPC and her second from Kiva. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family and to support the education of her children. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Chaker

texts.en:
Chaker is a 41-year-old married man with four children of whom three are still going to school.

Chaker works as a builder specialized in making concrete ramps. He has been involved in this occupation for the past twenty years and, over the years, he was been able to meet his family’s needs with his business.

On the business side, he has a growing number of projects. Today, he is requesting $1,000 to buy new molds to make new designs in concrete.

loans.use: To buy new molds to make new designs in concrete

loans.name: Bun

texts.en: Mr. S. is 26 years old, single, and lives with his mother in Phnom Penh city. He works as a driver for a private language school and earns a specific salary of $180 USD per month. S. normally takes a taxi or walks to work. He wants to have a vehicle but does not have sufficient funds to buy one. He is therefore requesting a Kiva loan to add to his small amount of savings to buy a motorcycle to ride to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Uk

texts.en:
Mrs. Uk C. is 41 years old and lives in Royak village, Takeo province. She is a pig breeder and, since her pig-breeding business is doing well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she is applying for 800,000 Riel from AMK to buy more piglets to raise and pig food.

Her husband, Mr. Sokhom Nov, is shown on the right in the photo. He is a worker in the rice-mill factory in the local village and is able to earn a small salary to support his family’s living. The couple have four children, one of whom is an employee in the garment factory and the others attend the local school.

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig food

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is a rice farmer. She is 38 years old, married, and has two children, her oldest being only eight years old.

Jocelyn’s one-hectare (2.5-acre) rice farm serves as the only source of income for her family. She has to work hard to make it productive so her family’s needs can be supplied.

Jocelyn is in need of additional capital for her farm and has applied for a loan of Php 7,000. With this amount, she will be able to buy certified seeds, fertilizer and other farm inputs.

loans.use: To buy certified seeds, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Rodelia

texts.en: Rodelia S. is married and is from the village of Langcataon, Pangantucan, Bukidnon. Rodelia owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store, selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Rodelia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from HSPFI. Rodelia is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in renovating her business. This loan will be her 2nd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in renovating her business

loans.name: Nasi

texts.en: Mrs. Nasi E. is 41 years old. She lives in the village of Prey Khla in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. She also breeds pigs in the house. Since her breeding is doing well, she wants to increase and expand it. So, Mrs. Nasi E. decided to ask for a loan to buy more piglets and pig food. With the rest of the loan, she will buy equipment to make palm sugar. Her husband, Mr. Samart Toem, collects juice from palm trees. Mrs. Nasi E. is the mother of five children. Two of her children are employed in a garment factory, and the others are students at a local school. (Her husband appears on the left in the photo.)

loans.use: To buy more piglets and pig food

loans.name: Judy

texts.en: Judy is a Kiambu-based businesswoman who operates a salon, a business she has run since 2004, in the Karia-Ikinu area. She offers hair dressing services and also sells beauty products. She describes her business environment as busy, and she sells her products and services to locals. She also earns extra income through dairy farming. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 KES in order to purchase cosmetics, a blow dryer, and a carpet for her business. A mother of two girls, Judy hopes to expand her salon business into a hair dressing institute and to own rental and residential units. She describes herself as aggressive, determined and self-driven.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics, a blow dryer, and a carpet

loans.name: Yaye Dié

texts.en: Ms. Yaye Dié T., aged 28, has a small tailor shop in the Grand Thies neighborhood of Thies, a city about 50 miles from bustling Dakar. Yaye has been in the tailoring business since 2000, creating dresses and traditional robes for her clientele – both male and female. Yaye's mother encouraged her to learn the trade and enrolled her in a three-year program to master the trade. Today, she has three young apprentices whom she teaches and who help her out with clients' orders. In the shop, she has three Singer sewing machines, and with her loan she will buy fabric, decorations, and other materials to keep the machines churning. Ms. T. is married and the mother of a five-month old child, and she also takes care of her young nine-year-old cousin. This is her second loan.

loans.name: Sairanbibi

texts.en:
Problems and money shortages never defeat Sairanbibi, who has always looked for a way to get past obstacles and continue to improve her situation. Sairanbibi is an extremely hard-working and energetic woman. She is 45 years old, a widow and the loving mother of two children. For more than five years, she has operated a store where she sells women’s clothes and shoes. Her store is well known and people love to visit because it's clean, tidy, and run by someone who is very kind and thoughtful. Sairanbibi hopes that her store will keep growing so that she can maintain a comfortable life for her two children. To make that possible, she has applied for a new loan that she will use to buy more clothing to sell. For this purpose, Sairanbibi requests $1500 USD. She promises to repay the loan with accuracy in the same manner as she did with the previous one. Sairanbibi is counting on your help. Be an important of the growth of Sairanbibi’s business. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the fourth millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

Moreover, it will help him get closer to his ultimate goal of purchasing a big store of his own.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing new goods for selling

loans.name: Mirzoulugbek

texts.en: Mirzoulugbek A. is 33 years old. He is married with four children. Mirzoulugbek lives in Istaravshan, Tajikistan, and has two hectares of land for cultivating cereals and vegetables. His wife helps him on the plantation. He now faces a small problem because he does not have enough money to buy seeds and fertilizer, so he decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. You could become an important part of his family's life. Mirzoulugbek deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Azizboy

texts.en: Azizboy D. has dedicated much effort to the business of agriculture for 20 years. He has land where produces different kinds of vegetables. He gets a rich harvest every year from his land. From the savings from his land, he could arrange the wedding of his two children. Currently Azizboy is asking for a loan of 7,000 Somoni in order to purchase fuels and lubricants, mineral fertilizer and saplings for expanding his business. Azizboy is very confident that he will be awarded this loan and assures you that he will repay the loan on time with no violations. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road, and for the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. loans.use: Purchasing fuels and lubricants, mineral fertilizer and saplings

loans.name: Khardiatou

texts.en: Ms. Khardiatou B. has worked as a community-health worker in the neighborhood of Cité Lamy in Thies since 1983. She supplements her income by selling beautiful fabrics called Thioup. Her husband used to work in neighboring Mali, where Thioup fabrics can be found at a much better price. He would buy the fabrics in the local market and send them to her in Thies. Now, however, her husband has returned home and she will make the journey herself to purchase the fabrics. The 150,000 franc loan will cover her transport costs and allow her to buy a dozen or so Thioup robes. She says this activity allows her to help meet the family's needs. She and her husband have six children and also take care of her mother and two nieces. Ms. B. has been a member of the IMCEC credit union since 2008, and is a member of the local PDEF (Development Program for Children and Families). Through the cooperation between the two organizations, her loan is financed on more favorable terms, including a reduced interest rate. The objective of the cooperation is to promote the income-generating activities of the parents of disadvantaged children in the PDEF program.

loans.use: Purchase Thioup fabrics

loans.name: Kagera Group

texts.en:
Mambo (greetings) from Tanzania! This is Liberita Y. and the Kabera loan group from the Kabera community in Dar es Salaam.

Liberita is 35 years old and is a widow with four children, 14, 11, 7 and 2 years old. She owns a tie-dye "batik" shop where she sells batiks, bras, and bedsheets. Her shop is open from 10 a.m. until 4 p.m. daily, and it is located in Kabera, the same district where she lives. She manages to make a monthly profit of 120,000 Tanzanian shillings (~90 USD). 

This will be Liberita's third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the first loans to buy bras and bed sheets to sell at her shop. She hopes to use this loan to expand her products. Now she would like to offer ladies sandals and headscarves for Muslim women, which are called "mitandiyo" in Kiswahili.

In the photo, Liberita is fourth from the right in the second row and is pictured with all fourteen of her group members. The other women run a variety of businesses which include clothes shops, charcoal sellers, a french-fry cook, and food vendors. The Kabera group thanks you for your support!

loans.use: To buy ladies sandals and headscarves

loans.name: Rizvon

texts.en:
D. Rizvon is 44 years old. She is a very wise and hard-working woman. She is married, with 4 children. This entrepreneur dedicates herself to the sale of clothing for teenagers. She started her business 15 years ago. Little by little, she has expanded her inventory and thanks to the good service she offers, her business is growing rapidly. She says that with income from her activity she is able to provide education and food for her children. Now Rizvon needs a loan of $1400 USD which she will use to buy clothing in order to fill her customers’ orders. This is the time to help someone who needs it. Please do not hesitate to help improve the quality of life of this family.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of winter clothing for teenagers to sell

loans.name: Hraj

texts.en: Hraj is a 38-year-old married man with 2 children. He has been working at selling and repairing jewelry since 1990. He learned this occupation from his grandfather when he was very young. He used to sit beside him and learn. Today, Hraj is asking to borrow US$ 700 to buy a laptop in order to help him in making jewelry designs.

loans.use: buy a laptop

loans.name: Kirima United Sande Scovia Group

texts.en: S. Scovia is a hard-working businesswoman of forty years, married with five children, all schooling. She has been operating a retail shop business for ten years. Due to having little capital she is using the loan to inject more capital into her business for improvement (sugar, soap, salt, flour, paraffin, bread, sodas, and so forth). She is a promising business lady whose future hope is to educate her children.

loans.use: To inject more capital into her business for improvement (sugar, soap, salt, flour, paraffin, bread, sodas, and so forth)

loans.name: God Grace Group

texts.en:
Anna G. is the leader of her five-person borrower group named 'God Grace'. Anna is 39 years old, married, and has five children -- two girls and three boys -- that range in age from 4 to 17 years old. Anna says that all of her children are attending school. Anna also helps support her mother, who lives in the countryside.
