Anna has a business selling foodstuffs such as beans, rice, and oil, and household staples such as soap. She has had her business in Thinker's Village near Monrovia for about four years, and says she ran a similar business elsewhere for about ten years before setting up shop where she is now. Her customers are people in her community.

Anna plans to use the proceeds of her 6,000 Liberian dollar loan (her share of the 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan) to buy more inventory for her shop. She buys from a large market in Monrovia, Liberia's capital, and transports the goods back to Thinker's Village about 20 kilometers away. She says her hope is to be able to continue to educate her children, and perhaps send some of them on to university one day.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Anna is at right holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy beans, rice, cooking oil, soap, and other items for a small general store

loans.name: Kamil

texts.en: Kamil is 46 years old. He is married and has 3 children. With his family he lives in Baku city. He has been in this business for 7 years. Now he needs a loan of 2000 AZN to buy spare parts for his taxi to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy spare parts for his taxi

loans.name: Tufanye Asaba Rosemary Group

texts.en: A. Rosemary, 21, is a hardworking business lady who is married and has three children, two of whom are going to school. She has been farming for three years. She is using the loan to get a tractor to plow her field, and to buy fertilizer, seeds, and so on to help her grow a better crop. She is a hardworking business lady who hopes to build a house in the future.

loans.use: To use a tractor to plow her field, to buy fertilizer, seeds, and so on for her farm.

loans.name: Cynthia

texts.en:
Cynthia H. is a 44-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy 1, Poblacion, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living selling dressed chicken and other frozen products.

Cynthia’s husband Ruel helps her run the business. They have four children who are currently going to school and who also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Cynthia Hisona joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life for their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by selling dressed chicken and frozen products. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 8,000 from her business activities.

Cynthia Hisona is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 15,000 was used to fund operations of her dressed chicken and frozen products business and it had a positive impact on both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is requesting her 11th loan, a loan of Php 19,500, which she intends to use to increase the inventory levels of her dressed chickens and frozen products. Cynthia Hisona is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which are to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon—a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Tufanye Mary Ofenzu Group

texts.en: Mary O. is a business lady who is 23 years old. She is married and has two children. She owns a pub where she sells drinks such as soda, water, beer, and so forth. She has been operating a pub business for one year. She is using the loan to purchase her pub items (mostly drinks like soda, water, beer, and so forth) for sale. She is purchasing much stock so that she is able to satisfy her customers' demand. She is a hardworking business woman whose dream is to build a house.

loans.use: To purchase pub items such as soda, water, beer, and so forth.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria has worked as a hairdresser in her home since 2005. She receives clients in her house, where she has prepared a special room for this purpose. She is known by her village neighbors. She is 23 years old and married with a newborn baby. 

Today, Maria is requesting to borrow $1,000 to buy beauty products and hair accessories needed to attract more clients and earn a good income to help her family.

loans.use: Buy beauty products and hair accessories

loans.name: Businge Nakayisigi Caroline Group

texts.en:
Caroline N., 48, is a businesswoman. She is married with eight children and she also looks after two siblings who are schooling. She has been in the foodstuff trade for over one year. 

She is using the loan to purchase items like cassava and sweet potatoes from gardens for sale. The loan is helping her add capital by stocking at least three to four bags of foodstuffs. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to earn a living.

loans.use: To purchase items like cassava and sweet potatoes from gardens to sell

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein has worked as a plumber, repairing toilets, faucets, etc., since 2006. He’s 18 years old, single and lives with his mother and three brothers. They cooperate together in the household. 

Hussein is very happy because he started a new business and so, a new career. Today, Hussein is requesting to borrow $600 to buy additional tools for his occupation because his work is growing and he needs to be able to meet the needs of the clients.

loans.use: Buy additional tools specified for his occupation

loans.name: Carmelita's Group

texts.en: Carmelita A. is from the village of Catabban, Burgos, Isabela. She is 39 years old. Carmelita is the group leader of a five-member group loan offered by ASKI, a Kiva partner. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Carmelita is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Carmelita runs a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Carmelita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the third loan taken out by Carmelita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Businge Nyadira Doreen Group

texts.en: N. Doreen has had a business selling tomatoes for three years so far. She is 25 years old and married with four children, three of whom are going to school. She is using her loan to put more capital into her business – she is purchasing tomatoes from farmers and transporting them to marketplaces. She is encouraged to work hard and her future hope is to build a good house.

loans.use: To purchase tomatoes

loans.name: Mercy Joy's Group

texts.en:
Mercy Joy U. is from the village of Villa Domingo, Angadanan, Isabela. She is 44 years old. Mercy Joy is the group leader of a 10-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Mercy Joy is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Mercy Joy owns and operates a business venture raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Mercy Joy has been engaged in her business for over ten years, and she earns approximately 20000 PHP every four months.

In 2009, Mercy Joy joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mercy Joy is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP, which will be used to purchase breeding livestock. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Mercy Joy from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI: 
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock for breeding

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad has owned a medical shop in his town since 2008 after seeing a need for such services in the region. He has specialized in selling medical supplies and equipment. He is a 52-year-old single man, living alone. Today, Mohamad is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase new medical supplies for inventory in his shop.

loans.use: purchase new medical supplies

loans.name: Everything Has Time Group

texts.en:
Quita V. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Everything Has Time. She is 35 years old and the single mother of six children between the ages of 3 and 17 years old, and their educational level is from kindergarten through eighth grade. She also cares for two sisters.

Quita and her family lives and works in Thinker’s Village, a newly established community at the southern outskirts of MonroV., the capital of Liberia. She was never able to go to school herself due to lack of financial support from her parents.

Quita’s business is bricks production. She buys cement in bulk and produces construction bricks to be sold to residents of Thinker’s Village. She has been running this business for eight years and hopes to own a building materials store in the near future.

Quita started by selling doughnuts and she managed to raise 6,000 LRD to get into bricks production. She produces strong and long-lasting bricks in order to encourage customers to continue buying from her. Quita needs this loan to purchase a load of sand for the production process.

She dreams of giving her children a good education and establishing businesses for them.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Quita V. is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: to purchase a load of sand for production.

loans.name: God Loves Us Group

texts.en:
God Loves Us is a group of five borrowers led by Fayieh L., who live and work in Westpoint, a very poor neighborhood near downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

Fayieh says he is 44 years old and married with four children between the ages of 8 and 22. He also cares for his siblings and parents. He is a high school graduate.

Fayieh’s business is his pharmacy, buying medicines wholesale and selling to the residents of Westpoint from his small shop. He has been running his business for six years. His dream is to grow his business until he can build a larger, permanent shop.  If he makes a good profit from his business, he dreams of sending his children to school and moving to a less dangerous neighborhood.

Fayieh's share of this 121,000 LRD group loan is 25,000 LRD.  He will use the money to buy additional pharmaceutical drugs wholesale to serve his customers in Westpoint.  Fayieh's God Loves Us group has already successfully repaid one Kiva-funded loan, and this is the second time his group has been posted to Kiva for funding.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Fayieh is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase medicines wholesale.

loans.name: Merlinda

texts.en:
Merlinda E. is a 43-year-old married woman who lives in the village of Sitio Old Fabrica, La Castellana, Negros Occidental. She earns her living raising and fattening pigs as well as running a general store.

Merlinda’s husband helps her in running the business and they have five children who are between 10 and 23 years old. Three of her children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores. The rest are already gainfully employed and help support the family.

Merlinda E. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in pig fattening and running a general store.  Now she earns an average monthly income of $176 from her business activities.

Merlinda E. is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of Php 29,500 was used to fund operations of her pig fattening and general store and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 16th loan, in the amount of Php 29,500, which she intends to use in pig fattening and general store businesses. Merlinda E. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned their respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.en:
Rosalia operates a spare parts business located off of a busy road in Kakamega, Kenya. She's been in the business for five years.

Rosalia is married and has one daughter - she hopes to improve her standard of living through working with SMEP to expand her business. In five years, she wants to be a wholesaler as well as a retail supplier of spare-parts. Rosalia describes herself as hardworking.

loans.use: To increase her stock of spare automobile parts

loans.name: Elevenia

texts.en:
Elevenia B. is a 35-year-old married woman who lives in the village of Sitio Old Fabrica, La Castellana, Negros Occidental. She earns her living from farming and running a general store.

Elevenia’s husband helps her in running the business and they have three children who are between 2 and 12 years old. Two of her children are currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Elevenia B. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in farming and running a general store.  Now she earns an average monthly income of $220 from her business activities.

Elevenia B. is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of 25,000 PHP was used to fund the operations of her farm and general store, and it had a positive impact both on the businesses and on the family’s living conditions. Now she is requsting her 14th loan, for the same amount, 25,000 PHP, which she intends to use on her farming activities and her general store business. Elevenia B. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned their respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional capital for her businesses

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.en:
Alejandra E. is a 41-year-old married woman who lives on the Site of Old Africa Brgy, Cabana-an Lal Castellana, Negros Occidental. She earns her living selling an assortment of goods and running a general store.

Alejandra’s husband helps her in running the business and they have six children who are between 9 and 22 years old. Some of their children are currently going to school and others are already gainfully employed, but they all help in supporting the family.

Alejandra E. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in the resale of an assortment of products and operating a general store.  Now she earns an average monthly income of $218 from her business activities.

Alejandra E. is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of 19,500 PHP was used to fund the operations of her general store and other business activities, and it had a positive impact on both the businesses and the family’s living conditions. Now she is taking out her 15th loan, in the amount of 19,500 PHP, which she intends to use to restock her general store and to buy other products for resale. 

Alejandra E. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet M. is a 31-year-old married woman who lives in the village Brgy Taliban, Himamaylan City, Negros Occidental. She and her husband support their family by selling food and by shuttling passengers around town on their tricycle (a motorcycle with a sidecar for passengers) for a set fee. 

Janet’s husband helps her in running her business. They have three children who are aged 7 to 11 years old, who are all currently going to school and also help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores.

Janet M. joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1999 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a food-vending business.  Now she earns an average monthly income of $117 from her business activities.

Janet M. is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of 13,000 PHP was used to fund the operations of her food-vending business, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 5th loan, in the amount of 15,000 PHP, which she intends to use on her food-vending business. 

Janet M. is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for food vending business

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali has owned a cleaning company since 1993. He got this idea after seeing a need for such services in the region.

He is 50 years old and married with three children.  He provides cleaners for companies and houses. He works upon the request of the customers. 

Today, Ali is requesting a loan of $1,200 to purchase a special machine that absorbs water and cleans the floors.

loans.use: purchase a special machine

loans.name: Hadi

texts.en: Hadi is an 18-year-old single man. In 2007, this young man decided to work as a builder and begin a new career. He learned this occupation from his two brothers. Today, Hadi is requesting a loan of $500 to buy a tractor, because this talented man is planning to enlarge and expand his business by taking more and bigger projects.

loans.use: to buy a tractor

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a 35-year-old retailer of molasses in Kakamega, Kenya. He has six employees and his business is located in a busy market center. He sells mainly to individual consumers, brewers of a special type of alcohol, and some companies. He faces constraints in acquiring molasses due to fluctuations in the availability of sugarcane. 

Paul is married and has two children and his hopes and dreams include securing a personal means of transportation. Eventually, he would like to sell molasses to big companies. He envisions himself as a risk-taker.

loans.use: To purchase more molasses

loans.name: Maria Engracia

texts.es: Maria Engracia es soltera, labora como recepcionista en el Hospital Asuncion desde hace varios años, tiene 2 hijas las cuales habitan con ella: la mayor Adis Noemi de 25 años que es madre soltera de un niño de 8 añitos de nombre Andy Jarott y la menor Glendy Fabiola de 18 años, ambas estudiando la universidad, esta solicitando su 8vo credito con el objetivo de hacer las divisiones de los cuartos con playsin, pues actualmente estan dividos con sabanas, y de esta manera contar con mayor privacidad tanto ella como sus hijas, espera contar con el apoyo de kiva para realizar este proyecto, pues con este financiamiento lograra mejorar las condiciones de vida de ella y sus hijas.
texts.en:
Maria Engracia is single and has worked as a receptionist in the Asuncion Hospital for many years. She has two daughters who live with her. The eldest, Adis Noemi is 25 years old and is a single mother of an eight year old son named Andy Jarrot. The youngest, Glendy Fabiola, is 18 years old. They both study in the university. Maria seeks this loan, her 8th, to create partitions in her home out of a sturdier material, since currently the room is divided by sheets, and she hopes to create more privacy for herself and her daughters. She hopes to count on the support of Kiva to complete this project, as with this financing she will be able to improve the quality of life for herself and her daughters.

Translated from Spanish by Michelle Harrison, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Division of rooms in home

loans.name: Mariana De Jesus

texts.es:
Mariana C. de 52 años de edad, vive en una zona periurbana ubicada en Paraíso de Guayaquil su casa es de cemento, su esposo le ayuda en el negocio no tiene hijos.

Mariana comenzó vendiendo pescados con su esposo, después de poco tiempo se compro un triciclo y implemento mas mariscos. Ahora ella y su esposo trabajan desde las 05h00 de la mañana hasta las 16h00 todos los días. Tienen un promedio de 20 clientes al día, venden cangrejos pescados de todo tipo, camarones. Una de los inconvenientes que tienen es cuando es veda de cangrejos y baja las ventas.

Con el préstamo quieren comprar cemento y piedras para poder construir mejor su vivienda. En el futuro quiere comprar un motor de lancha para solo dedicarse a la pesca de mariscos.
texts.en:
52-year old Mariana C. lives in a suburban area located in Paraíso de Guayaquil. Her house is made of cement. Her husband helps her with the business; she doesn’t have any children. Mariana and her husband began by selling fish only, and then a little while later she bought a food cart and sold shellfish too. Currently she and her husband work from 5am to 4pm every day. They have an average of 20 customers a day; they sell crab, all kinds of fish, and shrimps. One of their problems is when it is the closed season for crab, they make fewer sales. With the loan they want to buy cement and stones to improve the construction of their house. In the future Mariana wants to buy a motorboat so she can devote herself to catching shellfish.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy cement, stone

loans.name: Shawki

texts.en:
Shawki is a 55-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon with his wife and their six children. Shawki has been working in agriculture; he owns livestock. He produces milk and cheese. 

Shawki is exceptional in his work because he is known for his good production. His clients are people from his region. When he first started his business, he had to face competition, since in his region there is a lot of agriculture and livestock, so he had to make himself known to the public. 

Shawki decided on this business because of his experience. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to increase his livestock so that he would be able to increase his milk and cheese production and therefore, his income. This is his second loan cycle and he has always paid on time. 

In the future, he plans to keep on expanding his work by producing more.

loans.use: To increase his livestock.

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali has owned a barber shop since 2006. He is a 27-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, Southern Lebanon. Ali does his work well and is knowledgeable about new haircuts. His clients are people from his region. When he first started his business, he had some financial difficulties. Ali decided on this business to use his experience. 

Ali requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase air conditioning and repaint his shop interior to make it more attractive. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan. In the future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase air conditioning and repaint his shop interior

loans.name: Ali

texts.en:
Ali is a 25-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. Ali has been working as a house painter. He decided on this work because of his experience. When he first started his business, he didn’t face any difficulties except for making himself known to the public. Now, his clients are people from his region. Ali’s work is special because he does it well and is aware of the new painting fashions.

Ali is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase paint and tools for his work. This is the first time that Ali has requested a loan. He needs new tools so that he can do his best work. He hopes to continue improving his business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase paint and tools for his house painting business.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.es:
Luisa pertenece al banco comunal “VILLA RAYANNIYOC” de la Asociación Arariwa, tiene 50 años, es casada y tiene ocho hijos de los cuales cuatro son independientes y los demás están en el colegio. La ciudad de Rayanniyoc esta ubicado a unos 30 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.
  
Luisa se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como por ejemplo preparar desayuno y mandar a sus hijos menores al colegio. Luisa se dedica a la venta de cereales. La socia nos cuenta que los días miércoles, viernes y domingos vende sus productos en el mercado de Urubamba y los sábados lleva sus productos a la ciudad del Cusco y los vende en el mercado “Molino II”. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Luisa requiere el préstamo para comprar más productos como trigo, tarwi  y muchos cereales más. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Luisa belongs to the Villa Rayanniyoc Community Bank which is part of Kiva partner’s Arariwa Association. She is 50 years old, married, and has eight children, four of whom are independent and the others are in school. The town of Rayanniyoc is located about 30 minutes from Cusco. Luisa gets up very early to do the household chores such as prepare breakfast and get her younger children off to school. Her job is selling grain. On Wednesdays, Fridays, and Sundays she sells the grain in Urubamba market, and on Saturdays she takes it to Cusco and sells in the Molino II market there. She’s been doing this for several years, and all has gone well thanks to the effort she puts in to her work. She requires a loan to buy more products such as wheat, tarwi (Andean bean), and many other grains. Lucia is grateful for the opportunity to get this type of loan and promises to make the repayments according to the schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy more grains such as wheat, tarwi etc

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
Hussein is a 25-year-old man who lives with his wife in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. Hussein has been working as a floor polisher since 2002 and has stayed with it because of his experience. His clients are people from his region. Hussein performs his work especially well and is committed to it.

When Hussein first started business, he had difficulty buying the required tools for his work because he didn’t have enough cash. Now he is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase a new polishing machine. This is the first time that Hussein has requested a loan. In the future, he plans on continually improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase a new floor polishing machine for his work.

loans.name: Walid

texts.en:
Walid is a 26-year-old man who lives with his wife and their two children in Bint Jbeil, southern Lebanon. He has been selling aluminum to clients in his region since 2006. When he first started business, he had to face competition, but because of his experience he stayed with it. Walid’s work is special in that he performs it well.

Walid is requesting a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase more aluminum for his business. This is his second loan cycle; as for his first loan, he always paid on time. In the future he plans to continue improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase more aluminum.

loans.name: Chadi

texts.en:
Chadi has owned and operated a coffee shop since 2007. He is a 38-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, Southern Lebanon. Chadi's clients feel comfortable coming to his shop and enjoying a nice coffee or drink. His clients are his friends, neighbors, passers-by and people from his region. When he first started his business, he had difficulty purchasing all the necessary merchandise for his shop and he had to face competition. He decided on this business because he wanted to work independently and he also wanted to open a coffee shop. 

Chadi requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop and to change the décor of his shop to attract younger customers. This is his second loan cycle and he has always repaid on time. In the future, he plans to keep on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his shop

loans.name: Jose Absalon

texts.es: Jose Absalon de 28 años de edad es casado, tiene 2 niños: Jaquelin Daniela de 8 añitos y Jose Absalon de 7, ambos estudiando la primaria, su esposa Jaqueline se encarga del cuido de los niños y de la casa, ademas elabora manualidades como vestiditos tejidos, tapetes, pacheros y otras cositas, las cuales vende para apoyar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar. Jose Absalon trabaja como docente desde hace 2 años en la Universidad Nacional Agraria de Chontales impartiendo clases de matematicas los fines de semana. Los dias de semana atiende su pequeño negocio de venta y reparacion de celulares, para lo cual esta solicitando este financiamiento esperando ser beneficiado con kiva, pues desea comprar algunos repuestos y herramientas de trabajo (tenazas, desatornillador, otros) que le hacen falta para atender mejor a su clientela.
texts.en:
28-year old Jose Absalon is married and has two children: Jaquelin Daniela (8) and Jose Absalon (7). They both attend primary school. His wife Jaqueline takes care of the children and the house, and she also makes clothing, knitted items, table cloths etc. which she sells in order to help her husband with household expenses. Jose Absalon has worked as a teacher for two years at the National Agricultural University of Chontales. He teaches mathematics classes at weekends. During the week he runs a small business selling and repairing cell phones, and it is for this work that he is asking for a loan from Kiva. He wants to buy spare parts and tools (pliers, screwdriver, etc) which he currently lacks. Then he will be better able to serve his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: tools to repair cell phones

loans.name: Kassem

texts.en:
Kassem has owned a grocery store since 2000. He is a 57-year-old man who lives in Beirut, the capital of Lebanon, with his wife and their two children. Kassem sells canned food, candies, drinks, eggs, bread, etc. He also sells vegetables like lettuce, tomatoes, potatoes and others (depending on the season). Kassem knows how to treat his clients, who are his friends and neighbors. When Kassem first started his business, he had to face competition. He decided on this business because he wanted to work independently and use his experience. 

Kassem requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his store. This is his second loan cycle and he has always repaid on time. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his store

loans.name: Anwar

texts.en:
Anwar has been working in agriculture for over 30 years. He plants fruits and vegetables like tomatoes, watermelon, cucumbers, green beans, etc. He is a 59-year-old man who lives in Bint Jbeil, Southern Lebanon with his wife and their child. Anwar is known for his good production. His clients are people from his region. When he first started his business, he had to face competition since there is a lot of agriculture in his region. Anwar decided on this work because of his experience. 

Anwar requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to purchase new tools for his work. This is the first time that Anwar has requested a loan. In the future, he plans to keep on expanding his work and producing more.

loans.use: To purchase new tools for his work

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Selling generic medications

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Selling footwear

loans.name: Self Empowerment Group

texts.en: Self Empowerment is a group of five borrowers, led by Daniel K., living and working near Red Light, Paynesville. Red Light is Liberia's largest market, a bustling area near the capital (Monrovia) that is full of shops, stalls and vendor tables. Daniel is 37 years old and married with five children, aged 7 months to 16 years old. He also cares for two of his wife's aunt's daughters. Daniel is a high school graduate and went on to university but had to stop his studies after the first year due to a lack of money to pay school fees. Daniel’s business is selling kerosene. He buys wholesale in 55-gallon drums and then sells gallons of kerosene to his customers. Most of his customers are from rural areas and use the kerosene for lanterns and cooking. Daniel's share of this 27,000 Liberian dollar group loan is 6,000 Liberian dollars. He intends to buy more kerosene with the money from the loan. Daniel has been running his business for five years and this is his first loan from Kiva field partner LEAP. Daniel says the key to his success has been talking to customers in a good manner and sometimes he adds bonuses to their purchases to reward them. His dream is to own a gas station someday. If he makes good profits from his business, Daniel hopes to be able to educate his children as fully as possible, send his wife to school and complete his own university education. He also wants to build a house for his family. In the photo that accompanies this profile, Daniel is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more kerosene for resale

loans.name: Anastasio

texts.es:
Anastasio tiene 32 años, es conviviente y tiene tres hijos. Nuestro socio trabaja como albañil. El socio es un padre trabajador y emprendedor que saca adelante a su familia. Ya son tres años que es albañil y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo su esfuerzo que pone en su labor. El socio requiere el préstamo para comprar tejas, carrizos y adobes (El adobe es una pieza para construcción hecha con una masa de barro (arcilla y arena) mezclada a veces con paja, moldeada en forma de ladrillo) para construir su casa. El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.

Anastasio pertenece al banco comunal “VILLA RAYANNIYOC” de la Asociación Arariwa.  La ciudad de Rayanniyoc esta ubicado a unos 30 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco y donde los pobladores se dedican a la agricultura y ganadería.
texts.en:
Anastasio is 32 years old and lives with his partner and his three children. He works as a bricklayer. He is an enterprising father who works hard to get his family ahead. He is been a bricklayer for 3 years and it has gone very well thanks to all of the effort that he puts into his work. He needs a loan to buy roof tiles, reeds and adobes (adobe is a construction material made from a mass of mud of clay and sand, sometimes mixed with straw, that is molded into the form of a brick) to build his house. He is grateful for the opportunity provided through these means and pledges to make his payments on time. Anastasio belongs to the communal bank "Villa Rayanniyoc," which is part of the Arariwa Association. The city of Rayanniyoc is located some 30 minutes from the city of Cusco, and it is a place where the main economic activities are agriculture and livestock.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy roof tiles, reeds and adobe (sundried bricks) to build his house

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Selling lamp fuel

loans.name: Myriam

texts.es: Myriam de 40 años de edad es soltera, trabaja como responsable de riesgo laboral en la Empresa Medica Previsional Asuncion desde hace 18 meses, a pesar de no tener hijos siempre esta pendiente de su mamá apoyandola en lo que mas puede, esta solicitando su 4to credito con el objetivo de ver culminado todos sus esfuerzos de estudio, pues esta en el periodo de hacer el curso de graduacion y tramitar el titulo de Licenciada en Contabilidad Publica y Finanzas, y espera lograr ser beneficiada con el fondo kiva para realizar este sueño.  Ella se caracteriza por ser muy alegre, trabajadora, responsable, de buenas costumbres y con muchos deseos de superacion.  En el futuro desea estudiar un postgrado para poder tener mejores oportunidades de trabajo.
texts.en:
Myriam is 40 and single. Her work is being in charge of labor risks in the Empresa Medica Previsional Asuncion. She has been doing this for 18 months. In spite of not having children, she is always attentive to her mother and helps her as much as she can. She is asking for her fourth loan with the objective of seeing all of her educational efforts completed. She is now taking her graduation course, and is ready to process her title of being licensed in Public Accounting and Finances. She hopes to get a loan from Kiva to make this dream come true. She is characterized as being very happy, hard-working, and responsible. She has good morals and a great desire to succeed. In the future she would like to study a post graduate program to be able to have better work opportunities.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Graduation course and title processing fees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: the purchase of sheet metal and work equipment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Restaurant supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Storage and sale of grains

loans.name: Angélica

texts.es:
Angélica tiene 35 años, es conviviente y tiene tres hijos. Angélica se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como por ejemplo preparar desayuno y mandar a sus hijos menores al colegio. Angélica tiene su propia chacra donde siembra hortalizas y verduras. Angélica también se dedica a la crianza de animales menores como cuy, gallinas y chanchos. La socia nos cuenta que los días sábados lleva sus productos a vender al mercado de Wanchaq de la Ciudad del Cusco. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Angélica requiere el préstamo para comprar más semillas y alimento para los animales. Angélica pertenece al banco comunal “VILLA RAYANNIYOC” de la Asociación Arariwa.

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.

La ciudad de Rayanniyoc esta ubicado a unos 30 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.
texts.en:
Angélica is 35 years old. She lives with her partner and three children. Angélica wakes up very early to do her household chores, such as preparing breakfast and sending her younger children to school. Angélica has her own farm where she plants vegetables. She also raises small animals such as guinea pigs, chickens and pigs. She tells us that on Saturdays she brings her products to sell in the Wanchaq market in the city of Cusco. She has worked in this business for many years and has done well thanks to the effort she has put in to her work. Angélica needs a loan to buy more seeds and animal feed. Angélica belongs to the “VILLA RAYANNIYOC” community bank in the Asociación Arariwa.

She is thankful for the opportunity that this brings and also promises to complete all the payments according to schedule.

The city of Rayanniyoc is located 30 minutes from the city of Cusco.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase seeds and animal feed

loans.name: El Hadji

texts.en:
El Hadji Touré was the very first client to become a member of the Notto branch of UIMCEC. The branch opened in November 2009 to meet the demand for banking services in the rural community, situated about 20 kilometers from Thies.

Mr. Touré runs a small farming supply store, selling various products demanded by his local clientele. After finishing school, his father supported him in opening the business in 2000. On the side, he raises goats, a popular activity in Senegal.

Mr. Touré reports that the store has done well, and he hopes to open a second small store specializing in feed sales. With his loan of 150,000 XOF, he will replenish his stock of pesticides and other materials for the upcoming planting season. The income from his store allows him to take care of his own small family, as well as five members of his extended family.

loans.use: To replenish stock of farm supplies

loans.name: Modou

texts.en:
Mr. Modou N. is among the first clients to receive a loan from the recently established UIMCEC branch in Notto, a small rural community about 20 kilometers from Thies. The branch began its operations in November 2009, with the objective to meet the demand for credit by farmers and other entrepreneurs in the community.

Mr. N. has grown up in the area and knows farming well, as his father taught him from an early age. With his loan of 50,000 XOF, Mr. N. will purchase phyto-sanitaire, a pesticide, to protect his crop of potatoes, cabbage and other vegetables. Mr. N. is married and the father of two children, ages three and four. The investment to protect his crop will help guarantee income for the upcoming year.

loans.use: To purchase pesticides to protect his crop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase a motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Dried fish retail

loans.name: Elisa Lexania

texts.es: Elisa Lexania de 26 años de edad es casada, trabaja como maestra de primaria en el Colegio Enrique Tierno Galvan desde hace 3 años, tiene una niña de 4 añitos de nombre Ivonne estudiando preescolar, su esposo tambien imparte el pan de la enseñanza en una escuelita en Santo Domingo y asume los gastos del hogar. Elisa esta solicitando su 2do credito para construir un cuarto, ya que su vivienda la obtuvo por medio de un proyecto y solo consta de un pequeño cuarto y como esta embarazada de su segundo bebe desea contar con mayor comodidad cuando este nazca.  Elisa se ha caracterizado por ser muy responsable con sus compromisos, y es muy querida por sus compañeros de trabajo.
texts.en:
Elisa Lexania is 26 years old, married, and has worked as an elementary school teacher in the Enrique Tierno Galvan School for 3 years. She has a daughter named Ivonne who is 4 years old and goes to preschool. Her husband also teaches in a small school in Santo Domingo, and he assumes the household expenses. Elisa is requesting her 2nd loan to build a room, since she got her home through a housing project and it consists only of a small room. As she is pregnant with her second baby she would like to have a more comfortable home when this baby arrives. Elisa has been characterized as a person who is very responsible with her commitments, and she is very well liked by her colleagues at work.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to build a room

loans.name: Mawuli

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est un jeune homme célibataire, afin de subvenir à ses propres charges, il s’est lancé en 2007 dans la vente des produits de quincaillerie, il a ouvert sa propre boutique qu’il a appelé « ETS DAM » dans le quartier d’agoè qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé. Beaucoup d’entrepreneurs viennent acheter chez lui. Faisant face à une rupture de stock, il sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit afin de s’approvisionner avec 30 contreplaqués, 10 paquets de fils de rouleaux et des ampoules.
texts.en:
This gentleman is a single young man. To provide for himself, he started selling hardware in 2007. He opened his own store, which he named "ETS DAM", in the Agoe neighborhood at the periphery of Lome. Many entrepreneurs purchase from his store. Faced with a stock shortage, he is requesting his first loan from WAGES to replenish his stock with 30 plywood sheets, 10 packs of wire spools and light bulbs.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of hardware products

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes, age 30, is divorced and has two children who are both currently in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. She works hard to be able to provide for the family.

Agnes is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice porridge. She sells from a tabletop on the roadside in her community. Agnes has been in business for six years. She wants a loan in order to buy bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Akouvi Rose

texts.fr: Cette  dame réside dans le quartier  d’agoè atsanvé qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de Lomé, elle est mariée et mère de deux (02) enfants, en 2003 elle a commencé le commerce de charbons de bois  et d’ignames. Cela lui permet de contribuer aux dépenses de sa famille, elle s’approvisionne à l’intérieur du pays ans une petite ville appelée « Notsè ». Son stock de marchandises a un peu diminué, pour pouvoir se réapprovisionner elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 12 sacs de charbons de bois, 50 ignames, 03 sacs de maïs, 02 sacs d’haricots et divers.
texts.en:
This woman lives in the Agoè Atsanvé neighborhood, which is an outlying section of the city of Lomé. She is married and the mother of two children. In 2003 she began a business selling charcoal and yams. This allows her to contribute to her family expenses. She gets her supplies further inland in a small city called Notsè. Her supplies have diminished somewhat; in order to restock, she is seeking a loan from WAGES to buy 12 bags of charcoal, 50 yams, three sacks of corn, two sacks of beans, and other items.

Translated from French by Robin Clochard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal, yams, sacks of corn and beans

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy yams in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy bales of lingerie and jean material

loans.name: Tsomenefa

texts.fr:
Cette femme a commencé en 2006 le commerce de détail de produits génériques, elle exerce son commerce dans le marché local d’agoè assiyéyé. Son dynamise fait qu’elle est très connue dans le marché. Elle réalise de bonnes recettes. Actuellement son stock de produits génériques est en baisse, raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour se réapprovisionner avec 2 boîtes de RENFERO, 6boîtes de vitamines HECTO PEP, des EFELAGAN et PARACETAMOL, des perfuseurs et des seringues et divers.
Elle est célibataire, c’est avec le revenu de son commerce qu’elle subvient à ses propres charges.
texts.en:
This woman began a retail business of generic (pharmaceutical) products in 2006. She runs her business locally, in the Agoé Assiyéyé market. She is well known in the market due to her dynamism, and she generates good income. Currently her stock of generic products is decreasing to the point where she is requesting a loan from WAGES to replenish her supplies. She needs two boxes of RENFERO, six boxes of HECTO PEP vitamins, some EFELAGAN and PARACEMATOL, intravenous drip lines, syringes and diverse items. She is unmarried, and is able to support herself with her business earnings.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy generic products

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is a food vendor. She is divorced and the mother of five children, some of whom are in school. This 55-year-old woman lives with her children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. As a single parent, Ama works hard to be able to provide for the family. She prepares and sells a local dish called kenkey from corn dough. It is served hot with pepper and fried fish. Ama sells on a tabletop by the roadside in her community. She has been in business for 15 years and wants a loan to buy bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Luciana

texts.es:
Luciana tiene 42 años, es casada y tiene cuatro hijos. Luciana se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como por ejemplo preparar desayuno y mandar a sus hijos menores al colegio. Luciana tiene su propia chacra donde siembra hortalizas y verduras. Luciana también tiene animales como toros, gallinas y chanchos. La socia nos cuenta que los días jueves, martes y domingos, lleva sus productos a vender al mercado de Huancalle de la Ciudad del Pisaq. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. Luciana requiere el préstamo para comprar más semillas y alimento para los animales. Luciana pertenece al banco comunal “VILLA RAYANNIYOC” de la Asociación Arariwa.

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma. La ciudad de Rayanniyoc esta ubicado a unos 30 minutos de la ciudad del Cusco.
texts.en:
Luciana is 42, married, and has four children. Luciana gets up very early to do her household chores. For example, she makes breakfast and gets her younger children off to school. Luciana has her own farm where she plants vegetables. Luciana also has animals like bulls, hens, and hogs. She tells us that on Thursdays, Tuesdays, and Sundays she takes her products to sell them in the Huancalle Market in the city of Pisaq. She has been doing this for several years. It has gone very well for her thanks to the effort she puts into her work. Luciana needs the loan to buy more seeds and food for her animals. Luciana belongs to the Villa Rayanniyoc Communal Bank with the Arariwa Association. She is grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to pay it on time. The city of Rayanniyoc is located 30 minutes from the city of Cusco.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more seeds and food for the animals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Produce and sell palm oil

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida is 52 years old. She is a widow and has two children who are currently independent. She is a trader and trades in lingerie. She has basically supported her family through this trade. She started selling more than fifteen years, making her one of the famous sellers in the market. Vida is requesting for loan to buy bales of lingerie and jeans materials to increase her inventory and sales to make more income. She believes this loan would help her save some money and erect a shop where she can sell her stock.

loans.use: To buy bales of lingerie and jeans materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy groceries in bulk.

loans.name: Akouvi

texts.fr: Cette dame est divorcée de son mari  avec à sa charge ses 02 enfants, afin que ses enfants ne manquent de rien, elle s’est lancée en 2005 dans le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché de Lomé, elle a légèrement diminué le prix de vente de ses marchandises pour pouvoir attirer plus de clients, ce qui lui réussit bien. La demande actuelle de ses clients est très élevée et pour pouvoir tous les satisfaire, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 03 paniers de poissons congelés, 02 cartons de conserve, 3 paniers de légumes, un sac de maïs et un sac d’haricots.
texts.en:
This lady is divorced from her husband, and takes care of her two children. To ensure they lacked for nothing, she started a general grocery business in 2005. She gets her supplies from the great market in Lomé, and slightly lowers the sales price of her merchandise in order to attract more customers. This approach works well for her, to the point where customer demand is very high. In order to satisfy all her customers, she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy three baskets of frozen fish, two boxes of canned goods, three baskets of vegetables, one bag of corn and one bag of beans.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy general grocery products

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah is 34 years old. She is married and has six children who are in school. She works hard to help her husband provide for the family. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a mining community. Hannah has a bread baking business. She bakes bread in a conventional oven in her community and supplies to retailers and beverage sellers. She also trades in provisions and foodstuffs.  Hannah has been in business for three years and desires to expand her business. She requests a loan to procure bags of flour, sugar and other ingredients in bulk to be able to achieve her dreams.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Angel Maria

texts.es: Don Angel de 53 años de edad es casado, tiene 5 hijos, todos mayores de edad los cuales ya tienen su propia familia, trabaja como Jefe de Fiscalizacion en la Administracion de Rentas de Chontales desde hace 11 años, su esposa trabaja y le apoya con lo gastos de la casa.  Por medio de un proyecto obtuvo la oportunidad de tener su casa propia, la cual esta pagando y desea realizarle algunas mejoras, como es ponerle ceramica, pues las viviendas las entregan unicamente embaldozadas.  Espera contar con el apoyo de AFODENIC y Kiva para la realizacion de este pequeño proyecto, pues de esta manera su casa se vera mas bonita.  En el futuro espera seguir contanto con el apoyo de esta institucion para seguir mejorando su casa.
texts.en:
Angel is 53 years old, married, and has 5 adult children who each have their own families. He has worked as Chief Auditor in the Revenue Office of Chantales for 11 years. His wife also works and helps out with the household expenses. Through a housing project, he got an opportunity to have his own house, which he is paying for. He wants to make some improvements, such as adding ceramic tile, as the house was delivered with only concrete flooring. He is counting on the support of AFODENIC and Kiva in order to carry out this small project, since in this way he can make his home more beautiful. In the future he hopes to continue working with this institution in order to continue to improve his home.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to put ceramic tile in his house

loans.name: Zuela

texts.en:
Zuela is 34 and married with four children who are currently in school. She trades in grocery products like rice, fresh tomatoes, tinned tomatoes, cocoa products, skimmed milk, body pomade, etc. Her five years of experience in trading has made her one of the successful traders in her locality. 

Zuela considers the loan a great opportunity to expand her business to include other items frequently demanded by customers. She wants to use the loan to buy cartons of milk, bags of sugar, cartons of vegetables and palm oil to increase her stock of goods available for sale.

loans.use: To buy stock in bulk

loans.name: Jennifer

texts.en: Jennifer has been in the fish-selling business for four years. She is 23 years of age, married and has three children who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a commercial/mining community in Ghana. Jennifer works to support her husband financially. She supplies food vendors and retailers in her community. She procures her goods from nearby towns. She wants to expand her business by procuring goods in bulk with this loan.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish

loans.name: We Praised God Group

texts.en: We Promised God is a group of five borrowers, led by J. F., living and working near Red Light, Paynesville. Red Light, near the capital (Monrovia), is Liberia's largest market. It is a bustling area full of shops, stalls and vendor tables. J. is 77 years old and married with seven children, aged 17 to 42 years of age. He also helps care for two nephews and a niece. J. is originally from Lofa County in northern Liberia and grew up on a farm. As a child, he worked on his family's farm and never had the opportunity to go to school. J.’s business is selling traditional alcoholic beverages such as hard cane juice and root liquor. He buys wholesale and sells retail to customers. J.'s share of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan is 6,000 Liberian dollars. He intends to buy more wholesale hard cane juice and root liquor. J. has been running his business for more than 45 years and this is his first loan from Kiva field partner LEAP. J. says the key to his success has been talking to customers nicely. He sells from a table at the market now and hopes that one day he will be able to open a storefront. If he continues to have a profitable business, J. says he'll be able to take care of his family well. In the photo that accompanies this profile, J. is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution, with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy wholesale hard cane juice and root liquor

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 47 years old. She is widowed and has given birth to five children who are all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Axim. Axim is in the coastal area in the western region of Ghana. Fishing is the major occupation of the people. Grace is a food vendor. She prepares and sells a local dish called banku (cooked dough). It is served hot with soup. Grace has been in business for four years and wants a loan to buy bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Abena

texts.en: Abena is divorced and the mother of three children who are all in school. The 53-year-old woman lives with her children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. As a single parent, Abena works hard to be able to provide for the family. She is a food vendor. She prepares and sells a local dish called kenkey, made from corn dough. It is served hot with pepper and fried fish. Abena sells on a tabletop by the roadside in her community. She has been in business for 15 years and wants a loan to buy bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Olga Lidia

texts.es: Olga Lidia A. López desde hace cinco años decidió tener su propio negocio que consiste en un bar y billar. Este se localiza  por la terminal de interlocales de León  y buses en el mercado Israel. Según A. este tiene mucha concurrencia debido a que esta cerca de la Terminal de buses y muchos mientras esperan ingresan a distraerse.
texts.en:
Five years ago Olga Lidia A. López decided to have her own business, which consists of a bar and billiard’s table. This is located at the inter-urban bus station of Leon in the Israel Market. According to A., it is very busy because it is near the bus station, and while they wait a lot of people enter to entertain themselves.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy beer

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is 62 years old. She is married with five children. Currently her children are independent but she lives with two of her grandkids. She sells cocoa drinks, meat pies and spring rolls in a community school around her neighborhood. Schoolchildren in Ghana enjoy cocoa drinks and meat pie as a snack. Cocoa drinks are prepared with cocoa powder, mixed with water, sugar and milk and put into a refrigerator in sachets. The schoolchildren enjoy ithe drinks with meat pies and spring rolls. It is the main source of income for her to support her household. She makes a profit of GHS 5 – GHS 7 a day. With the loan, she wants to buy cocoa powder, sugar, vegetable oil and flour in bulk. She believes the loan would enable her to increase her profits and save more to support her grandkids in school. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr: Cette femme a appris le métier de couture et s’est installé depuis 2004 à son propre compte, elle sait très bien coudre, ce qui attire beaucoup de personnes, elle veut associer à son activité la vente des articles de mercerie,raison pour laquelle elle sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour l’achat de 14 rouleaux de popeline, 12 petits rouleaux de fil, des fermetures de pantalon, 5 boîtes  de boutons et divers.
texts.en:
This woman has acquired sewing skills and started her own business in 2004. She is a fine seamstress, which attracts many customers. She would like to diversify her activities by selling haberdashery items, which is why she is requesting a first loan from WAGES. The loan will be used to buy 14 bolts of poplin fabric, 12 small spools of thread, zippers for pants, five boxes of buttons and various other items.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy haberdashery items

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is 37 years old. Married with five children, Ama works to support her husband economically. She lives with her husband in a rented apartment in a mining community. Ama trades in pastries (meat pies). She prepares the pasties and supplies them to retailers in her community. She has been in business for 14 years and wants to give her business a facelift. Ama requests a loan to procure bags of flour, sugar and other ingredients in bulk to be able to supply to more customers.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Philomena

texts.en: Philomena is 40 years old. She is married and has given birth to four children. All of her children are still in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing-dominated community. Philomena works hard to help her husband provide for the family. She trades in cereals such as beans, maize, rice, etc. She supplies to retailers and food vendors in her community. Philomena also treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. She has been in business for over 12 years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk. She is expecting to increase her profit when she receive the loan to provide more support to her kids education.

loans.use: To buy cereals in bulk

loans.name: Gladis Del Socorro

texts.es: Gladis del Socorro M. M. de 41 años desde hace cinco años sale de su casa a tempranas horas ofertando en las casas, empresas e instituciones que se encuentra en su ruta de trabajo cosméticos y prendas de oro y plata. Esta inicio con este negocio para ayudar en su hogar y para que sus hijos tengan una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Gladis del Socorro M. M. is a 41-year-old woman who has been leaving her home very early in the morning to sell cosmetics and gold/silver jewelry at homes, companies, and institutes for five years. She started this business to help out in her household, and so that her children could have a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics and gold/silver jewelry

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian is married and the mother of four children who are all currently in school. The 45-year-old woman lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. She works hard to help her husband provide for the family. Vivian is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice with stew. She sells on a tabletop by the roadside in her community. She buys her raw materials from nearby towns. Vivian has been in business for 18 years and wants a loan to buy bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Ana Carolina

texts.es:
Ana Y. de 19 años, vive en una zona periurbana en la Perimetral de Guayaquil, solo tiene agua y luz como servicios básicos, no esta casada ni tiene hijos.

Ana comenzó hace ya un año atrás con el negocio de las cabinas telefónicas con la ayuda económica de su novio que esta en el extranjero. Poco a poco ha implementado vitrinas con productos Yanbal como perfumes y cremas. Ana trabaja todos los días desde  las 07h00 hasta las 21h00 con la ayuda de su hermana dando servicios de telefonía local, extranjera etc. Una de las complicaciones que tiene son los racionamientos de energía que hace el gobierno.  

Con el préstamo quiere comprar una fotocopiadora para implementarla en el negocio. En el futuro quiere terminar sus estudios de Marketing y Negociación y poner su propio local.
texts.en:
Ana Y. is a 19-year-old woman who lives in the Perimetral de Guayaquil area. The only utilities she has are water and power. She is single and has no children.

She started her call shop a year ago with the financial support of her boyfriend, who is currently abroad. Little by little, she has been filling up display cases with Yanbal products, such as lotions and fragrances. Ana works every day from 7:00 am until 9:00 pm with her sister’s help. Together they provide local and long-distance phone services. One of her biggest obstacles is the power rationing that is done by the government.

With this loan, she would like to purchase a photocopy machine. In the future, she would like to finish her Marketing degree and own a business space.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a photocopy machine

loans.name: Corazoncito Group

texts.es: El grupo Corazoncito está integrados por tres mujeres trabajadoras y muy unidas que se apoyan entre ellas.  Una de estas es Thelma O. quien desde hace 15 vende comida y gaseosa en su casa de habitación y las distribuye en diferentes centros de trabajo. Asimismo Brunilda L.  vende comida y gaseosa y  Ivana C. comercializa de forma ambulante  ambientadores y cloro.
texts.en:
The Corazoncito Group is comprised of three very hardworking and united women who support each other. One of those women is Thelma O., who has been selling food and soft drinks both from home and at different workplaces for 15 years. Brunilda Lopez also sells food and soft drinks, while Ivana Castillos sells bleach and air fresheners as a street vendor.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase ingredients like staple grains, vegetables, meat, etc.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 32 years old. Married with five children, Agnes works to support her husband economically. She lives with her husband in a rented apartment in a mining community. Agnes trades in pasties (meat pies). She prepares the pasties and supplies to retailers in her community. She has been in business for nine years and wants to give her business a facelift. Agnes requests a loan to procure bags of flour, sugar and other ingredients in bulk to be able to supply to more customers.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is married and the mother of six children who are all currently in school. She is 45 years old and lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. She works hard to help her husband provide for the family. Grace is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice with stew. She sells on a tabletop by the roadside in her community. She buys her raw materials from nearby towns. Grace has been in business for over 20 years and wants a loan to buy bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Ligia Del Socorro

texts.es: Doña Ligia es soltera, madre de 2 hijos: el mayor que ya tiene su familia y trabaja como tecnico en rayos X y la menor que estudia la universidad.  Ligia trabaja para el Hospital Asuncion de Juigalpa desde hace 12 años como Enfermera, brindandole cuidades a aquellos que lo necesitan. Actualmente habita junto a su mamá,  pues a pesar de tener su vivienda no ha logrado habitarla debido a que le faltan ciertos detalles, pues con los creditos que ha obtenido de AFODENIC ha logrado acondicionarla poco a poco, por lo que esta solicitando su 9no credito con el objetivo de terminar de construir el porche de esta, pues  tiene levantado la mitad y desea cerrarlo con verjas de hierro alrededor y comprar la puerta de hierro para brindarle mayor seguridad a su casa, ya que como trabaja por turnos la casa queda sola y quiere prevenir cualquier inconveniente.  Doña Ligia se ha caracterizado por ser muy responsable con sus obligaciones y muy trabajadora.
texts.en:
Ms. L. is a single mother with 2 children; the eldest works as an X-ray technician and has his own family, while the youngest is a college student. Ligia has been working as a nurse at the Hospital Asuncion de Juigalpa for 12 years, providing care to those who need it. She is currently living with her mother because despite the fact that she has her own house, she has not been able to occupy it since it still needs to have some work done. She has been able to equip it little by little thanks to the loans that she has received from AFODENIC. She is now requesting a 9th loan with the aim of finishing work on her porch since she is already halfway done. She would like to put up wrought-iron bars around it and purchase a wrought-iron door in order to make her home safer. Because she works different shifts and the house is unoccupied, she wants to prevent any problems from arising. Ms. L. is noted for being very hardworking and very responsible with her obligations.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Install wrought-iron bars around porch

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida is married and has three children who are all still in school. The 40-year-old woman lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in one of the mining towns in Ghana. She works hard to help her husband provide for the family. Vida is a food vendor.  She prepares and sells porridge prepared from millet. She sells on a tabletop by the roadside in her community. Vida has been in business for some years now and wants a loan to buy bags of millet and other ingredients in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy soft drinks in bulk

loans.name: Doña Blanca Group

texts.es:
El grupo Doña Blanca desde está integrado por tres mujeres trabajadoras y joviales. Una de ellas es su fundadora por la cual el grupo tiene este nombre esta es la señora Blanca Mercedes C. G..

C. es una señora muy mayor en la cual se nota sus años de arduo trabajo, la experiencia tiene y sus deseos por una vida mejor. Ella cuenta con la ayuda de  sus nietas e hijas quienes trabajan en la tortillería supervisada por ella. 

Esta señora con su sonrisa franca, sus bromas y  su afecto se ha ganado el cariño, respeto y admiración de sus compañeras. Estas son  Segundina  G. quien desde tempranas horas sale a vender de hot doc y Ana Mercedes B. la cual en las primeras horas de la mañana está echando tortilla.
texts.en:
The Doña Blanca Group is comprised of three hardworking and cheerful women. One of those women, Blanca Mercedes C. Gonzales, is the founder of the group, which is named after her.

Ms. C. is an older woman, which is clearly evident from her years of hard work, her experience, and her desire for a better life. She has the help of her daughters and granddaughters who work in the in the tortilla factory that she supervises.

This woman has gained her fellow group members’ respect and admiration with her sincere smile, her jokes and her affection. Those group members are Segundina G., who sells hot dogs very early on in the morning, and Ana Mercedes B., who starts making tortillas at the crack of dawn.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase corn

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa is fifty years old. She is married and has five children who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a mining and commercial community in Ghana. Adwoa trades to help her husband financially take good care of the family. She trades ready-made clothes and dressing bags for ladies. Adwoa hawks and treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. She has been in business for ten years and wants a loan to procure clothes and other dressing accessories in bulk.

loans.use: To buy clothes and bags

loans.name: Fati

texts.en: Fati is fifty five years old. She is married with a four children. Currently only two of her children are in school; the others have completed school and are working. She is a food vendor and sells waakye. Waakye is cooked rice and beans enjoyed with stew, macaroni and fish. It is sold in the mornings as breakfast. She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of rice, beans, gallons of oil, fish, etc. to enhance her food production. It is her greatest desire to expand her food business and improve upon her standard of living.

loans.use: To buy raw material.

loans.name: Old Ladies Group

texts.en:
Kebbeh M. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called Old Ladies Group. She is 60 years old and is married with 4 children, but she can’t remember her children's ages, because she did not go to school due to poverty. She also cares for 2 nephews.

Kebbeh and her family live in the Coca Cola factory community in Paynesville, but sell in the Red Light Market near Monrovia, which is the biggest market in Liberia.
